segments.text: I have the pleasure and honor of interviewing Colonel Fred Dollar today.
It's Groundhog Day, 2nd of February, 1999, and we're in the conference room in the Evans Library.
Colonel Dollar, to start with, for the sake of those who may listen or read this in years to come, give us a brief biographical summary of your life until you came here to A&M to work.
We'll do another one on your student days here.
But where did you grow up, and when were you here, and what did you do after you left campus before you came back?
I grew up near Henderson, Texas.
I was born on a farm or ranch combination where I learned some hard work and honesty and the things that families used to be taught.
And did well through high school, got interested in debate.
It was an old town, old country, but when the Beast Texas Oil Field came in, that changed the whole complexion.
So that gave us a little ambition to spread out.
So I came down here to school in 1940.
I had a scholarship at Baylor, but I didn't go there because I had hay fever so badly.

and i guess this is the worst place i could come to but i did at any rate so i came down here worked and left before i could finish because of we were we were inducted into the army in 1943 but i had enough grade points so that when i got my commission i completed my number of hours so they sent me my diploma in 1946 so i served in the military
until 1965.
Various parts of the world, regular U.S. Army, where I learned quite a few things.
A lot of them I did not want to learn, but I did.
And so that's the sum total of what happened before I came.
Alright, so you got out of the Army in 1965.
To come here.
And how did you and A&M get together then?
Well, I had worked
This has nothing to do with that immediately, but I had worked in the dining halls for Cliff Hotard when I was a student.
Oh, yes.
Well, in about 1964, I wrote a letter to one of the trade magazines in which I mentioned Texas A&M University.
in the sense that they had an article on the Navy food service.
So I said, Texas A&M's usually about 20 years ahead of the Navy.
Why don't you do an article on Texas A&M?
Well, I had met Earl Rudder, so I put a little note on a copy, and I just said on the note, you might get a kick out of this.
Well, I was about ready to return to the continent of the United States,
in 1965, and I had a letter from Clark Monroe who said, President Rudder brought me a letter from you, and he wondered if you might be interested in a job at this institution.
He said, would you come and take a look at it?
So I told my wife, I'll go just for fun, it won't amount to anything.
I did.
I went back and told her virtually the same thing.
But then I had a telegram, in essence, to come quickly as you can.
So I retired and came here.
It was about, oh, I realized if I got any older, I'd have difficulty finding something anyway.
So that was after 22 years of military service.
So I came here in 1965 and worked immediately under Howard Vestal,
Over him was Tom Cherry and then Earl Rudder.
And I believe those were three of the greatest men that I have ever known.
They were just outstanding in every respect that I have the greatest respect for them.
All right, now let's talk about those three men because that's one of the clear important points.
First, let's back up.
When you came to visit the campus that first time with the possibility,
What did you, where did they take you?
Who did you meet with?
Well, I just really met with those three people.
And I stayed, spent the night in the Memorial Student Center and talked at length with the dinner that night and with Howard and Clark Monroe and their wives.
And that was about it after we surveyed everything.
I didn't really look at any food facilities, because actually they were exactly the same as they were when I left here.
And had I known how dilapidated they were, I might not have come.
But I had been hoping to return to this part of the country, but never thought about coming here.

did they during this visit did they sit you down and interrogate you was there a oh no no they had looked into my background i found out later through the association of former students uh because they they knew people people here knew people there who knew me there so they they corresponded with them a little bit to find out what kind of person i might be here
Now, Clark was the Director of Personnel.
Personnel.
And then Howard was...
He called it Auxiliary Services then, and later Business Services.
And then Mr. Cherry was the Vice President... President for Business Affairs, which included the Fiscal Affairs.
And then Mr. Rutter was President.
Describe, make believe someone hadn't ever seen Howard.
describe him physically and then describe him in terms of his way of getting things done?
Well, he was a very intelligent man, very cordial.
And he told me, he said, I've been here only a month.
And actually, I was the first person he ever hired.
And he said, he told me that many times, but he's just a cordial, outgoing, open individual.
And he didn't know a lot of things about the school particularly.
One time he told me, he said, you know, I regret I'm not an Aggie.
I said, Howard, you were a better Aggie the day you got here than a lot of people will ever be, which was true.
And so it was just a casual, informal meeting.
I think President Rudder made so many decisions, and I think he really made the decision because we went down to interview President Rudder all the time.
Describe that.
Well, we went in to see him, and he was always outgoing, very friendly.
We had a little conversation about the military and just a little bit about the school.
And he says, well, I wonder how hard you work.
I said, President Rudder, my middle name is work.
And beyond that, it was just a small talk.
And that was the whole conversation then.
There was no question about any technical information I had.
I mentioned a little experiences, I believe, to Howard, but beyond that, we didn't talk about that either.

It was just a fact I think that I already talked to people and knew some of the jobs I'd been in, and President Rutter was very prone to hire military people, apparently, which I didn't know when I came here.
But then I learned that so many around were following him.
I never would have guessed that.
His office was then down in what we...
In the system, old system.
The one right...
Right.
Now the Williams building.
Yes.
Let's see.
He didn't claim to be highly informed about food service.
No, no, no, no, no, he didn't.
And they didn't know of any changes that one had made.
It was just wanted somebody to come and do the job.
Why was the job vacant?
Frank Nugent had been food director here for a short time, probably the shortest tenure anyone ever had in that job.
And he had left shortly before that.
Later on, I told Mr. Cherry, I said, you didn't necessarily need me, but you needed somebody immediately.
And I think that might have been part of it.
Did they offer you a salary and you accept, or was there some?
No, that's very interesting.
They offered me a salary, and I said, well, I would like to come for that, but I can't.
because I said I have some obligations, including some sick children at the time, and I said I must meet those expenses, and I said otherwise I'd be delighted to come.
And then we left it like that.
That's one of the reasons I told my wife when I returned, I said we can just forget it and enjoy the trip.
But they decided to give me whatever I said I needed,
A hired vessel later on said, you're making more than I am.
Of course, I'm sure that didn't last very long.
All right, so you arrived then and began August 10, 1965.
1965, all right.
And describe the responsibilities and facilities for which you were responsible.
Well, I had just about total responsibility about as much as you can get for anything because Howard didn't believe in real close supervision, and neither did Mr. Cherry.
So the facilities I had were Sabiza Hall, Duncan Hall, Memorial Student Center Food Services, Hotard Hall, believe it or not,
Hotard Hall was not Hotard Hall then.
It was a hall behind the post office, that is the campus post office, where we kept laborers who wanted to live there alone.
We had many that had come in from various places, and some had been there for years, some who were single.
Then we had a facility, Bryan Field, that small group,
And beyond that, we had in the summertime a training camp at Junction, which is now Texas Tech property, arranged by one of our previous governors.
And that was it.
It was very limited.
There were no snack bars like there are now.
And the MSC had to serve as both snack bar and formal dining.
A very restricted facility, by the way, compared to what we now have.
and what we later built.
About how many employees?
Oh, we had, I started with about 600, and well, that was the summertime.
We wound up with, or late, we wound up a little later with 800 employees.
Of course, in the summer, one of the things that makes this job different from others as director of food services is that you have a tremendous group in the fall and main year you need.
Then you must drop down to tremendous loads.
And that's the reason when you budget, you must budget for about 170% more than your average sometimes because they have to be there
when you need them and reduced when you don't need them.
As you began, who were your key subordinates?
Describe who they were and what they did.
Well, we had some old-time chefs who had been here for, one of them I worked with in Sebiza, I had worked with when I was a student.
Now, I worked really
Under him, in an indirect way, Hoketard said I was his employee, but this was Mr. Willie Yeager, who's one of the world's greatest people, I guess.
And he was a ball of fire, had been there for years.
So we had him, and we had Mr. Plant and Duncan Hall, who had been here for years.
And then we had hired
Frank Nugent had started this just prior to my arrival, managers of the dining halls, which were called Miss Halls then.
And they were Army sergeants.
One fellow had come out of the Navy, but had quite a bit of knowledge of food and somewhat more formal dining affairs.
than our old time chefs had here.
And then we had a manager at the Memorial Student Center.
But they were all, all those people were fine people, but they were not really what we needed to grow with, not because they were incapable, they just had not been over that hurdle previously.

for the big affairs that you and others have witnessed here at a and which we built a lot of our pr later on because you arrived at about the time the growth in the enrollment was beginning just before it took off i suppose and uh we we later on had some what what we tried to do
was to make a public relations affair out of everything we had at the Memorial Student Center.
Now, we had a long time and a hard time getting into this because to hire people at very low salaries a lot of times, it was very difficult.
I had some notes here to tell you one of the occasions we had that I'll never forget.
We had two long 60-foot buffet tables.
that was shrub trees and decorations of every type.
This was one of the president's buffets, which you have attended many times.
And Governor Clements came in and he, one of the board members introduced him to me and he came in and we shook hands when he entered.
And he came in and he looked at that food display
with those two 60-foot lines and all the things on it and the aroma coming off.
And he grinned from ear to ear and he said, let me shake your hand again.
Well, that was what we were trying to develop.
And in a sense, that happened many times because on every occasion of those things, we not only had that mapped out down to the minute and the item and the people and everything,
But we'd have a meeting after each one of those affairs to critique it and see, well, what could we do to make this president's buffet greater than it was the last time?
On one occasion, Howard Bessel said to me, what did you serve?
I said, Howard, we served everything we could think of.
He said, that's great.
Because he wanted us to do everything we could do.
In other words, he wanted...
And I wanted, as you and others wanted, to be the best at everything we did.
Well, if you try hard enough, sometimes you will.
Now, there must have been some great successes, meals, some big meals that you remember.
What were some of the biggest ones that you can recall in terms of the crowd and the success?
Well, some of the biggest ones were just small affairs.
I don't mean small in numbers, but not with great importance attached to them like the 4-H Club.
We fed those people.
That was one of the things that was an outstanding accomplishment, I think,
We filled Cebiza upstairs and downstairs with about 4,000 people in a very short time.
And to feed that many in a short time was unheard of in many places.
What would have been the menu?
Well, for that number, we had a
We had one item which was chicken on that occasion with the vegetables and dessert and the salad and such.
But what we did was a system that was later put into dunking.
This is where the idea came from for that arrangement that's there now.
Where they passed down this, we were assembling plates as fast as they could walk.
So we were able to serve that number
And about the time it would take you to go down a cafeteria line over here in one of the commercial cafeterias.

And this is a system we use in developing the Dunkin' Dining Center, which is now a center that can be used continuously if it needs to be with thousands of people for self-service with not only with one item, it has a variety of menu items that can be served.
We developed three different systems here, really, for the first time.
And we had a lot of firsts, not because we were trying to get firsts, but it just developed that way.
When we renovated Sbiza Dining Center, we had the first comprehensive fast food in conjunction with a regular menu that had ever been offered in the United States.
About when was that?
That was in 1976.
and it wasn't completed until 77.
And there we had where you walk up and get the hot pizza, the hamburgers, and the other fast foods.
And the first
The first time we offered, we'd offer those items one at a time, and it'd be such a shock to students that line up out the door.
First time they'd ever been served hot pizza anywhere, because that just couldn't be done for student dining.
Same way with hamburgers.
They were coming right off the line, and it worked quite well.
Then when we opened Commons Dining, down where we have Kruger, Dunn, Moser, Astin,
We developed there what we called an accordion style.
And we did it by necessity, not to be smart or outstanding or anything.
It was just something we had to do.
We divided a long cafeteria line that would have been long into several sections with duplicate meats.
and vegetables so that we duplicated everything in just a few feet and put little bars about an inch high so that people couldn't slide their trays that got off the beat.
And we could serve in a line that would only serve one person, we could serve five people at a time.
And it was amazing how fast that went.
And then the third thing, we call that the accordion style.
Then in Duncan Dining Center, we developed this concept of having all of the salads and the beverages outside where people could pick them up as they came in, that is the customer.
And then a variety of foods
at different stations they could see and go directly to and take whatever they wanted and then go back for all they wanted when they finished that.
And for lack of a better name, we called that plate ready because we were assembling the plates as they came along so the Corps can eat rapidly in great numbers.
And that's the first time that we had that for the Corps because this school, when I came here, was all family-style service.
And the military academies are still family-style service.
Now, we had people from all over the United States to come look at the facilities and those dining arrangements.
And the Army used those as some of their examples in improving their new designs for their dining facilities.
Now, I don't think they did a good job of it, but their consultants came and looked at those, and they came back the second time, and they paid us a great compliment.
In fact, they mentioned us in some of their publications, but they said, we find problems other places.
We find solutions here.
Well, that might not be entirely true, but it's nice to hear sometimes.
Where did you turn...
as you were trying to bring about these changes and advancements, where did you turn for ideas, advice, counsel?
Well, I had studied a lot of this in the military because I'd been in supply work primarily, purchasing, storage, supply, transportation of food.
I'd been in charge of this in Korea and the Far East.
So I had seen that, and I knew that was not what we wanted.
So I started looking at all the outstanding commercial places and institutions that I could identify to get ideas where I could put them together.
And from that, from what I already knew, we came up with these different things.
Where did you get some of the good ideas?
Can you name some specific?
Well, I think University of Tennessee.
I used to say I'd steal these ideas.
And I'd steal them from almost everywhere.
From SMU, I stole an idea or two.
From the Humble Building in Houston.
And almost any place I'd go, I'd try to find something that I could use, some little something.
And it worked pretty well.
I think it worked today, really, because you never do reach perfection in this or anything else, in most cases.
Now, you were in charge from 65 till?
To 87.
87, right.
When you started out, you said six to seven hundred employees.
What was it when you retired?
Well, we had gotten up to...
It seems like we'd gotten about 8,000, but my numbers might be a little bit off.
All right, and then do you remember what the annual budget was?
Yes, when I retired, it was probably about close to five million.
Do you remember what it was when you started?
No, but I knew it had been quite a long, probably maybe a third, not even a third of that, I think.
When you started, the workforce was made up of men, women, black, white?
Mostly men.
Very few women.
A mixture of black, white, and Spanish.
And one of the amazing things that was originally needed, what was then, what is now Hookard Hall, was that we'd solicit often in order to get people to work.
We would solicit people in South Texas with the radio stations would do this free for us, public relations on their part.
So we'd hire people, and we might have hired many wetbacks.
I don't know.
But we had everybody that would come.
We would hire them.
And a lot of them wouldn't stay but a week or two, and that was a very difficult thing.
We were paying so little, it was ridiculous.
Do you remember what the pay was then?
Well, I remember, I believe one of my outstanding cooks made 86 cents an hour.
And that was a commitment for 13 hours a day because it was a split shift.

And that is where, for anyone that wouldn't know, where you come in early in the morning, you work until the afternoon, then you get a break for two or three hours, then you're back working in the evening until the work is finished.
And some of those poor fellows never saw all their homes, I think, in the daylight, except in the summertime.
and sometimes on the weekend, and they were paid on a basis of an eight-hour shift for that 13, 14-hour obligation.
One of the comical things that I think about often is that one day when it became obvious that we were the only ones still trying to do this, or one of the few, I said, we're going to change this.
We're going to have two shifts every day.
Some of the old-timers said it won't work.
I said, well, it works everywhere else seemed like.
They said, yes, but it won't work here.
And so can you imagine what trouble we would have been in with the government if we had tried to continue a split shift?
It was terrible.
Well, the beautiful thing about all this was that people like Howard Vestal and Tom Cherry
We're just 100% behind everything I did.
One of the greatest things I read happened to me one day before we started most of this building program.
Hired a best with Ken Burnett and said, well, he said, I want you to know, Mr.
Chair and I have talked, we want you to build anything you need.
Well, that was music to my ears.
Now, we made our own money, and a lot of people didn't know that.
They thought we got money from the state

somewhere else but we generated our own money but but we had to get once it came in it was under school state control so we had to get permission and spend it so we we were woefully low on salaries and on monies for our facilities and to the extent it was it was almost pathetic well the first thing we started on was to renovate
Subiza, we mentioned before.
One of the few things I've done before that, we had no color on campus.
You'd be surprised at how drought everything was.
There was a little bit of color in Memorial Student Center, but very little, very little.
A carpet on the rug would have been forbidden like this one here.
It was just, it couldn't be tolerated.
Well, I painted the entrance of the basement to Subiza chartreuse.
And it looked so conspicuous, I thought I'd probably be called on the carpet for it.
And now that would be a jubilee, of course.
But that's just how things were.
Everything was tan or brick red or brown.
And that was the color scheme.
All right, you get here in 65.
What was the first major change that you undertook?
Well, I believe that was a renovation of Sebesa.
I really worked on that 10 years.
I'm slow, so I worked on the renovation of Duncan.
The thoughts and the diagrams, that is 10 years.
I worked 10 years on Sebesa.
I told somebody once I couldn't do anything less than two years.
Were the food preparation facilities located at each of the three
Sebesa, Duncan, and the MSC, they prepared their own?
You didn't bake it at one place and take it over there?
The only central production was the bakery at Duncan, and we baked everything there.
There was a rumor for the students at Duncan over in the Corps that everything was cooked in Sebesa.
Well, I wanted to have a little fun out of that, so in the basement of Sebesa, when we did one of the conversions,
named the basement the Underground and then the one section the Underground Railroad and we built a caboose and so that I said yes there it is we use this train from this point to transport the food
Well, you know, I never heard the rumor after that day.
It was so ridiculous.
Not even they could.
They had to laugh at it.
You mentioned bakery.
